Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 12:29AM cathy67 wrote: Hi, your situation is quite similar to mine. Mine is most likely benign, and I don't have chance to talk to the radiologist, who recommends me for a core biopsy. I googled and learned, and confirmed with breast surgeon, that this kind of biopsy will insert a metal clip into woman's breast for surgery location, if no surgery afterwards, then it will be there forever. Lots of women complainted its side-effects. So I have the choice, to go, then 5% (say) comes out not b9, 95% comes out a whole rest life side effect, not go, 5% is not b9, 95% still has a nice life. I am in Canada, that is a screening mammography, also my first one, a very dense breast, and Asian woman. I rarely see Asian woman in that mammography clinic. I am 44 years old, almost 45.
Posts.Title: Should I get a second opinion angel1985 cathy67

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 06:21AM cathy67 wrote: Hi Letlet, I don't know my situation, really. But the report said "most likely benign", that is the original wording. It is good you guys in States can look for second opinion so easily, just bring your film or CD. I had been staying in States for one year, I know the private insurance there. In Canada, everything is covered by government, so I don't need to care about the expensive fee, but everything is controlled by others. It is almost two months after my first mammography, I am still waiting for the biopsy schedule. Unfortunately, I can not be offered three month mammopgraphy followup, only six month, otherwise I just go ahead for this appointment.
